description.narrative: Support to combat elephant poaching in Niassa National Reserve, Mozambique

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This project will provide core support to wildlife protection staff in Mozambiques largest remaining elephant population. Activities will include aerial surveillance, deployment of a rapid reaction anti-poaching team, field ranger training, and supplying salaries and rations to anti-poaching patrols.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Curbing the impact of trade-motivated poisoning on Endangered vultures in southern Africa

description.narrative: this project will reduce the number of vulture mortalities due to poisoning in Africa by providing appropriate guidelines in the form of a best practice manual and by training key conservation staff in southern Africa to effectively manage and investigate poisoning incidents when they occur. A comprehensive database will be used to record details of incidents and to assess the effectiveness of these interventions.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Protecting an important elephant sub-population in Niassa National Reserve, Mozambique

description.narrative: Aerial surveys conducted in 2014 reveal significant declines of Mozambiques elephant numbers. Its most significant population, in Niassa, in northern Mozambique, declined 63% in three years, from 12,000 elephants in 2011 to 4,441 in 2014. In order to reduce poaching and halt the decline of the Niassa elephant population, this project will collar select representatives within significant cohesive herds or concentrations of elephant family groups in order to focus anti-poaching and security efforts around intensive protection zones for the remaining significant herds of elephant in NNR.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Aerial surveillance and deterrent for elephant protection in Chuilexi Conservancy, Niassa Reserve, Mozambique

description.narrative: This proposal focuses on the Chuilexi concession within Niassa Reserve in northern Mozambique. Activities will include operating costs for an airplane in order to improve monitoring and detection of poaching threats, and to improve the ability of law enforcement personnel from Chuilexi and the greater reserve to respond to elephant poaching incidents and other illegal activity.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Greater Limpopo Lion (and Elephant) Conservation Program

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in the Mozambican component of the Greater Limpopo Transfrontier Conservation Area, including the Limpopo National Park through the targeted removal of snares and poisoned bait from key areas used by resident lion prides and the targeted protection of elephants leading to a significant decrease in lion and elephant poaching and a measurable increase in the abundance of lions and elephants.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Greater Limpopo Lion (and Elephant) Conservation Program

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in the Mozambican component of the Greater Limpopo Transfrontier Conservation Area, including the Limpopo National Park, through the targeted removal of snares and poisoned bait from key areas used by resident lion prides, and by improving the protection of elephants through targeted anti-poaching exercises. Specific activities will include: (1) targeted snare removal and poisoned carcass removal from key areas used by resident lion prides; (2) targeted snare removal in key potential lion habitat to facilitate the natural re-colonization of lions; (3) targeted protection of elephants by providing advanced training and mentoring in anti-poaching to Limpopo NP rangers; (4) development of elephant poaching database; and (5) implementation of targeted monitoring of lion and elephant status and poaching trends to enable adaptive conservation management of the regions wild lion and elephant population.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

Specific activities will include: (1) targeted snare removal and poisoned carcass removal from key areas used by resident lion prides; (2) targeted snare removal in key potential lion habitat to facilitate the natural re-colonization of lions; (3) targeted protection of elephants by providing advanced training and mentoring in anti-poaching to Limpopo NP rangers; (4) development of elephant poaching database; and (5) implementation of targeted monitoring of lion and elephant status and poaching trends to enable adaptive conservation management of the regions wild lion and elephant population.

title.narrative: STRENGHTENING ANTI POACHING OPERATIONS TO PROTECT ELEPHANT IN CHUILEXI CONSERVANCY, NIASSA RESERVE MOZAMBIQUE

description.narrative: The projects long-term goal is to strengthen protection and anti-poaching effectiveness for elephant within Chuilexi Conservancy and for Niassa Reserve.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Strengthening anti-poaching operations to protect elephant in Chuilexi Conservancy, Niassa Reserve, Mozambique

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to strengthen protection and anti-poaching for elephants in the Chuilexi area of the Niassa area in northern Mozambique. Elephants in Niassa are under severe threat and now number fewer than 2,000 (<10% of the population ten years ago). In addition to protecting elephants, this project also benefits all of Niassas wildlife, including important populations of lions and buffalo. This proposal is for a twelve-month period. Objectives include strengthening anti-poaching efforts (through provision of new uniforms and supplies for 62 scouts and equipping patrol teams with handheld radios), improving coverage and response rate of anti-poaching patrols during the wet season (by procuring a patrol boat and initiating water-based patrols on the Lugenda River), and supporting the canine unit (through training for dogs and handlers and operational expenses for deployments).

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING ANTI-POACHING OPERATIONS AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT TO PROTECT ELEPHANTS IN A CRITICAL AREA OF NIASSA RESERVE, MOZAMBIQUE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support an elephant conservation effort in Niassa Reserve by maintaining and strengthening anti.poaching efforts in a severely depleted elephant population in northern Mozambique. Estimated to contain over 12,000 elephants.in 2011, the Niassa National Reserve (now the Niassa Special Reserve) is reported to have lost over 60% of its elephants by 2014.during a poaching surge described as one of the most catastrophic declines on the continent. One of multiple concession groupings.within Niassa, the Chuilexi Conservancy is believed to contain a disproportionate number of the remaining elephants and will be.an important source population for the Reserve' s recovery if a recent reduction in poaching can be maintained. Specific activities.include: (1) maintaining anti-poaching operations, including support for patrol transport, equipment, and aerial monitoring; (2).improving monitoring and protection capacity, including an upgraded operations rooms for law enforcement, and training in law.enforcement monitoring and decision-making software systems; (3) conducting public engagement and outreach with local.communities and protected area staff related to recent changes to national wildlife legislation, increasing support for local.communities and improving collaboration with stakeholders in neighboring lands; and (4) supporting local communities with.socio-economic development challenges, including food security, education and health factors, including monitoring fencing and.responding to human-wildlife conflict incidents, providing secondary school scholarships to local children, and supporting the.flying doctors program, which provides medical aid to Niassa communities.

title.narrative: COMMUNITY OWNED ELEPHANTS COEXISTENCE CORRIDOR IN SOUTHERN MOZAMBIQUE

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN THE MAPUTO PROVINCE BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND PROMOTING HUMAN ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE. LOCATED WITHIN THE GREATER LIMPOPO TRANSFRONTIER CONSERVATION AREA (TFCA) SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS LANDSCAPE IS HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 47,405 ELEPHANTS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC), HABITAT LOSS, AND POACHING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) DEPLOYING ELEPHANT GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) COLLARS AND ANALYZING THEIR MOVEMENTS TO SUPPORT CORRIDOR PLANNING AND DESIGN (2) IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL HEC HOTSPOTS WITHIN CORRIDOR ZONES AND ALIGNING ELEPHANT MOVEMENTS WITH HEC RAPID RESPONSE UNITS (3) FACILITATING INFORMATION SHARING WITH COMMUNITIES AND CO PRODUCTION OF HUMAN ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE TOOLKITS (4) CONDUCTING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMMING AND SKILLS TRAINING WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS, WITH AN ADDED FOCUS ON WOMEN AND (5) CONDUCTING CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS THAT PROMOTE PRO ELEPHANT INCOME GENERATING OPPORTUNITIES, INCLUDING BEEHIVE AND CHILI FENCES, UNPALATABLE PERMACULTURE GARDENS, CRAFT SALES, AND TREE PLANTING AND PROTECTION.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date
